# Dynatrace Naming Standards

## ActiveGates

### [**ActiveGate Groups**](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/activegate-group)

The ActiveGate Group Name should indicate where the ActiveGate is
located, and what functions it is expected/allowed to perform.

Examples: OnPrem_Routing, Azure_Routing, OnPrem_Extensions,
Azure_Extensions, OnPrem_Synthetic_Location, Azure_Synthetic_Location
(where Location can indicate more about the location as needed).

### [**Network Zones**](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/network-zones)

Network Zone names should clearly reflect the location of the ActiveGate
and can be derived from this verbose example:
provider.region.availability-zone.datacenter.tier, and following the
best practices of using a period as the delimiter and using lower case
letters. 

Example: onprem.1425, azure.eastus.zone1

## OneAgents

### [**Host Groups**](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/host-groups)

Host Groups are an extremely important configuration item as they
control how individual hosts can be configured as a group rather than
one by one, they allow filtering down to specific sets of hosts in the
UI easily, and they control how processes and services are grouped and
split. A process group or set of services can only belong to a single
host group.

The general rule of thumb with host groups is that the "application" and
the "environment" are key parts of the name. An additional part can be
the "function" or "tier" (such as "web", "app", "db", "queue", and so
forth.

There is a tradeoff in the granularity choice of using or not using the
function/tier part in that if you elect not to use it, you will not be
able to edit hosts as a group as well so if you want different
thresholds for CPU for a web server vs an app server vs a database
server, you will need to edit individual hosts (or use the API or other
means to automate it).

If you do elect to use function/tier as part of the name, you will end
up with more process groups and more services, often with the same
names, which can make it confusing to navigate the UI and know what is
being looked at.

Another choice is which delimiter to use to separate the "parts" of the
name. Generally, an underscore or a hyphen are the choices here. If one
of the parts of the name typically contains one of these characters, it
is best to go with the "other one" to avoid parsing issues (as we often
use regex to parse the host group to obtain the individual "parts" for
tagging).

Deciding on upper-case only, lower-case only, or mixed case is also
important.

Mixed case can be problematic in that it allows too much creativity and
tends to lead to non-standard names and confusion.

Examples:

accounting_prod, ACCOUNTING_PROD, Accounting_Prod, Accounting_PROD,
Accounting_prod, prod_accounting, prod_accounting_web,
accounting_prod_web, accounting_web_prod.

Note that the addition of function/tier complicates the choice of
ordering so that parsing can always be consistent. Also, there is almost
always an "application" and an "environment", but function/tier can be
more "optional", so we run the risk of complicating the parsing.

## Dynatrace UI

### [**Management Zones**](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/management-zones-hub)

It is recommended that a prefix be used to identify the type of
filtering being done. For example: "env: prod" might be used for a
filter of "all prod entities", "os: windows" for all windows entities,
"app: accounting_prod" for filtering for an application in production,
and "app: accounting_web_prod" for filtering on just the accounting
production web servers (if the function/tier is included in the host
group, or if we can identify the function/tier in another manner, such
as host property or part of the host name.

Examples:

env: prod

os: windows

app: accounting_prod

app: accounting_web_prod

app: accounting (for all accounting app entities, across all
environments)

Management Zones can be created manually, or using automation.

### [Security Context](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/access-security-context)

[Security
Context](https://docs.dynatrace.com/docs/shortlink/access-security-context)
is used to limit user access and can also be used for filtering (via a
segment). This is similar to, and will soon replace, Management Zones,
which can also be used for both filtering and access control.

Unfortunately, the mapping of these two elements is a bit cumbersome so
far.

There is the easy option of using an out of the box capability that
copies the management zone to the security context. Alternatively, you
can set the property directly for maximum future-proofing.

Given the plan for Management Zones to be retired in the future, the
recommendation is to set the security context using the
"dt.security_context" host property.

Generally, the security context should be identical or similar to the
host group, or to the "application" part of the host group. If
function/tier is part of the host group, it would likely be left out of
the security context, as it would be unlikely that access control would
need to be that fine-grained. If there is no need to allow access to the
"environment" (prod vs uat) then just the application name would
suffice.
